description.narrative: Projektet kommer att följa och stödja de pågående reformprocesserna inom den serbiska administrationen som berör den demokratiska kontrollen av säkerhetssystemet. Det kommer att fungera framst genom att stärka kapaciteten hos parlamentet och det civila samhället för att utföra tillsyn av säkerhetssektorn.

The project will follow and support the ongoing reform processes in the Serbian administration in relation to democratic oversight of the security sector. It will primarily support the strengthening of the capacities of the Parliament and the civil society to exercise oversight of the security sector.

participating-org.narrative: OSCE/Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2014Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The results shown in this memo concern the whole duration of the project, from April 2013 to December 2015.
The project achieved a significant progress towards its key objectives and contributed to increased transparency of the security sector institutions, building a solid ground for further strengthening of the parliamentary oversight and control of the security sector, influencing increased interaction between the civil society and security sector institutions and fostering education and research on security-related issues.
More specifically, the project achieved the following results:
- A pilot course on security and defence for MPs has been launched at the National Defence School of the Military Academy, providing a basis for a more sustainable mechanism for continuous in-house education. A group of 14 MPs completed the course and acquired certificates; - A number of seminars have been held for the members of the Committee for Defence and Internal Affairs and the Committee for Control of Security Services covering a variety of topics: internal control mechanisms in the police, the control of security services, gender equality in the security sector and budget control in the security sector. - Study visits to Switzerland and Belgium have been organized for the two Committee members as an opportunity to learn about the ways the control of security services and the police can be organized. - Emergency management simulation exercises and trainings in rescue and protection have been held for 113 emergency team commanders (majors, municipal heads, heads of districts) - Strategic Planning Department of the Ministry of Defence has made a study trip to UK to acquaint themselves with the strategic planning processes in defence and security area. The visit was followed up with an in-depth course in Belgrade delivered by the UK experts. - 16 small-scale civil society projects covering a broad range of security-related issues have been supported. These can be classified in three categories: research projects, educational projects or advocacy projects. Besides capacity building to grantees, these projects helped improve the communication and cooperation between the civil society and security sector institutions. - A course on gender and security has been introduced at the Faculty of Political Science, as a part on the MA Program on International Security. The course has been integrated in the regular curriculum, which made it fully sustainable. - 17 MA and 16 PhD scholarships have been awarded to students both to security sector employees and civilians. The scholarships concerns the studies of security concepts and security governance at the Faculty of Political Science and the Faculty of Security. An Alumni Academic Network has been created to provide a platform for exchange of experience and resources among the scholarships' recipients and enable them to take a more active part in the security sector reform processes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
